item.title: Port numbers
item.dc:creator: marnanel
item.description:
We should ensure that AP URLs can contain port numbers. I believe this is the single most helpful thing that we can provide to people experimenting with server software.

At present, some clients restrict port numbers to 443, sometimes trying 80 first. A person can install any package they like, but to test it they need both root access and a separate publicly-visible hostname and IP address which isn‚Äôt already running a web service. This can be a tall order.

This may be the case for some servers too‚Äî I don‚Äôt know. But I think everyone should check their code, client or server, to ensure that port numbers work.

This also applies to custom protocols such as Mastodon!

(Possible #hackathon topic?)

item.title: Debian now has a Fediverse Packaging Team
item.dc:creator: schmittlauch
item.description:
Debian now has a Fediverse Team which focuses on packagin Fediverse software for Debian.

This happens together with Debian launching its own Social Team and launching own instances of Pleroma, Peertube, WriteFreely and Pixelfed for project members.

I am neither affiliated with Debian nor one of the mentioned teams, but just found these news relevant.

item.title: About the Packaging category
item.dc:creator: decentral1se
item.description:
A place to discuss the packaging and distribution of federated applications for the purposes of making self-hosting more accessible.

We want to discuss how to help make it easier for all technically curious people to deploy federated applications on their self-hosted homebrew servers or VPSes.

This means creating a space for developers, users and packagers to meet and discuss. We invite projects like YunoHost, Freedom bone and Freedom box as well as other similar projects to participate.
